	  open pwt56\char95{}60\char95{}89.dat 
	  (* for 1989 (last obs), lag 29 gives 1960, the first obs *) 
	  genr gdp60 = RGDPL(-29) 
	  (* find total growth of real GDP over 30 years *) 
	  genr gdpgro = (RGDPL - gdp60)/gdp60
	  (* restrict the sample to a 1989 cross-section *) 
	  smpl -r YEAR=1989 
	  (* Convergence?  Have countries with a lower base grown
	  faster? *) 
	  ols gdpgro const gdp60 
	  (* result: No! Try inverse relationship *) 
	  genr gdp60inv = 1/gdp60 ols gdpgro const gdp60inv 
	  (* No again.  Try dropping Africa? *) 
	  genr afdum = (CCODE = 1)
	  genr afslope = afdum * gdp60 
	  ols gdpgro const afdum gdp60 afslope2

{9\p@}}ols\endSeq{}\endNode{} command gives special output in a loop
      context: the results from each individual regression are not
      printed, but rather you get a printout of (a) the mean value of
      each estimated coefficient across all the repetitions, (b) the
      standard deviation of those coefficient estimates, (c) the mean
      value of the estimated standard error for each coefficient, and
      (d) the standard deviation of the estimated standard errors.
      This makes sense only if there is some random input at each
      step.\endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%

{0}\def\Lines%
{asis}\def\InputWhitespaceTreatment%
{preserve}}
	(* create a blank data set with series length 50 *) 
	nulldata 50 
	genr x = uniform() 
	(* open a loop, to be repeated 100 times *) 
	loop 100 
	genr u = normal()
	(* construct the dependent variable *) 
	genr y = 10*x + 20*u 
	(* run OLS regression *) 
	ols y const x 
	(* grab the R-squared value from the regression *) 
	genr r2 = \$rsq 
	(* arrange for statistics on R-squared to be printed *) 
	print r2 
	(* save the individual coefficient estimates *) 
	genr a = coeff(const) 
	genr b = coeff(x)
	(* and print them to file *) 
	store foo.dat a b endloop
    \endPar{}\endNode{}\endPar{}\endSeq{}\endDisplayGroup{}\endNode{}\Node%

      open greene11\char95{}3.dat 
      (* run initial OLS *) 
      ols C 0 Y 
      genr essbak = \$ess 
      genr essdiff = 1
      genr b0 = coeff(Y) 
      genr gamma0 = 1 
      (* form the linearized variables *) 
      genr C0 = C + gamma0 * b0 * Y\char94{}gamma0 * log(Y) 
      genr x1 = Y\char94{}gamma0 
      genr x2 = b0 * Y\char94{}gamma0 * log(Y) 
      (* iterate OLS till the error sum of squares converges *) 
      loop while essdiff > .00001 
      ols C0 0 x1 x2 -o 
      genr b0 = coeff(x1) 
      genr gamma0 = coeff(x2) 
      genr C0 = C + gamma0 * b0 * Y\char94{}gamma0 * log(Y) 
      genr x1 = Y\char94{}gamma0 genr x2 = b0 * Y\char94{}gamma0 * log(Y) 
      genr ess = \$ess genr
      essdiff = abs(ess - essbak)/essbak 
      genr essbak = ess 
      endloop 
      (* print parameter estimates using their "proper names" *) 
      genr alpha = coeff(0) 
      genr beta = coeff(x1) 
      genr gamma = coeff(x2)
      print alpha beta gamma

	Carries out Augmented Dickey\Character{8211}Fuller tests on the null
	hypothesis that each of the variables listed has a unit root,
	using the given lag order.  The cointegrating regression is
	estimated, and an ADF test is run on the residuals from this
	regression.  The Durbin\Character{8211}Watson statistic for the
	cointegrating regression is also given.  Note that none of
	these test statistics can be referred to the usual statistical
	tables.

      Windows\Character{8212}these won't mean anything to me.)\endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%

{1}}For all datasets, multiple precision calculations

	numbers and all calculations were made with this very high
	precision. The results were output in multiple precision, and
	only then rounded to fifteen significant digits.

	computational inaccuracies, and will produce results which
	differ slightly from these certified values.\endPar{}\endNode{}\endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%

{1}}As mentioned in the main text,
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3487}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{} offers a reasonably full
	selection of least-squares based estimators, plus a few
	additional estimators sych as (binomial) logit and probit.
	Advanced users may, however, find
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3488}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{}'s menu of statistical
	routines restrictive.\endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3489}}\Par%
{\def\FirstLineStartIndent%
{0\p@}\def\FirstLineStartIndentFactor%
{0}\def\Quadding%
{justify}\def\Hyphenate%
{1}\def\Language%
{EN}\def\sbNom%
{5\p@}\def\sbMin%
{5\p@}\def\sbMax%
{5\p@}\def\sbConditional%
{1}\def\saNom%
{5\p@}\def\saMin%
{5\p@}\def\saMax%
{5\p@}\def\saConditional%
{1}}No doubt some advanced users will prefer to write their
	own statistical code in a fundamental computer language such
	as C, C++ or Fortran.  Another option is to use a relatively
	high-level language that offers easy matrix manipulation and
	that already has numerous statistical routines built in, or
	available as add-on packages. If the latter option sounds
	attractive, and you are interested in using free, open source
	software, I would recommend taking a look at either GNU R
	(\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3490}}\Seq%
{}\Seq%
{}\Seq%
{}r-project.org\endSeq{}\endSeq{}\endSeq{}\endNode{})
	or (\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3491}}\Seq%
{}\Seq%
{}\Seq%
{}GNU Octave\endSeq{}\endSeq{}\endSeq{}\endNode{}).
	These programs are very close to the commercial programs S and
	Matlab respectively. 
      \endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3492}}\Par%
{\def\FirstLineStartIndent%
{0\p@}\def\FirstLineStartIndentFactor%
{0}\def\Quadding%
{justify}\def\Hyphenate%
{1}\def\Language%
{EN}\def\sbNom%
{5\p@}\def\sbMin%
{5\p@}\def\sbMax%
{5\p@}\def\sbConditional%
{1}\def\saNom%
{5\p@}\def\saMin%
{5\p@}\def\saMax%
{5\p@}\def\saConditional%
{1}}
	Also as mentioned above, \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3493}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{}
	offers the facility of exporting data in the formats of both
	Octave and R.  In the case of Octave, the
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3494}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{} data set is saved thus: the
	first variable listed for export is treated as the dependent
	variable and is saved as a vector, \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3495}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}y\endSeq{}\endNode{}, while
	the remaining variables are saved jointly as a matrix,
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3496}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}X\endSeq{}\endNode{}. You can pull the \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3497}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}X\endSeq{}\endNode{}
	matrix apart if you wish, once the data are loaded in Octave.
	See the Octave manual for details. As for R, the exported data
	file preserves any time series structure that is apparent to
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3498}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{}. The series are saved as
	individual structures. The data should be brought into R using
	the \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3499}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}source()\endSeq{}\endNode{} command.
      \endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3500}}\Par%
{\def\FirstLineStartIndent%
{0\p@}\def\FirstLineStartIndentFactor%
{0}\def\Quadding%
{justify}\def\Hyphenate%
{1}\def\Language%

{1}\def\saNom%

{5\p@}\def\saMax%
{5\p@}\def\saConditional%
{1}}
	Of these two programs, R is perhaps more likely to be of
	immediate interest to econometricians since it offers more in
	the way of statistical routines (e.g. generalized linear
	models, maximum likelihood estimation, time series methods).
	I have therefore supplied \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3501}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{}
	with a convenience function for moving data quickly into R.
	Under \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3502}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{}'s Session menu, you
	will find the entry \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3503}}\Seq%
{}\Character{8220}Start GNU R\Character{8221}\endSeq{}\endNode{}.  This writes
	out an R version of the current
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3504}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{} data set
	(\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3505}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}Rdata.tmp\endSeq{}\endNode{}, in the user's gretl
	directory), and sources it into a new R session. A few details
	on this follow.
      \endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3506}}\Par%
{\def\FirstLineStartIndent%
{0\p@}\def\FirstLineStartIndentFactor%
{0}\def\Quadding%
{justify}\def\Hyphenate%
{1}\def\Language%
{EN}\def\sbNom%
{5\p@}\def\sbMin%
{5\p@}\def\sbMax%
{5\p@}\def\sbConditional%
{1}\def\saNom%
{5\p@}\def\saMin%
{5\p@}\def\saMax%
{5\p@}\def\saConditional%
{1}}
	First, the data are brought into R by writing a temporary
	version of \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3507}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}.Rprofile\endSeq{}\endNode{} in the current
	working directory.  (If such a file exists it is referenced by
	R at startup.)  In case you already have a personal
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3508}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}.Rprofile\endSeq{}\endNode{} in place, the original file is
	temporarily moved to \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3509}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}.Rprofile.gretltmp\endSeq{}\endNode{},
	and on exit from \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3510}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{} it is
	restored.  (If anyone can suggest a cleaner way of doing this
	I'd be happy to hear of it.)
      \endPar{}\endNode{}\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3511}}\Par%
{\def\FirstLineStartIndent%
{0\p@}\def\FirstLineStartIndentFactor%
{0}\def\Quadding%
{justify}\def\Hyphenate%
{1}\def\Language%
{EN}\def\sbNom%

{1}\def\saNom%
{5\p@}\def\saMin%

{5\p@}\def\saConditional%
{1}}
	Second, the particular way R is invoked depends on the
	internal \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3512}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}gretl\endSeq{}\endNode{} variable
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3513}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}Rcommand\endSeq{}\endNode{}, whose value may be set under the
	File, Preferences menu.  The default command is
	\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3514}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}RGui.exe\endSeq{}\endNode{} under MS Windows. Under X it is
	either \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3515}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}R --gui=gnome\endSeq{}\endNode{} if an installation of
	the Gnome desktop (\Node%
{\def\Element%
{3516}}\Seq%
{}\Seq%
{}\Seq%
{}gnome.org\endSeq{}\endSeq{}\endSeq{}\endNode{}) was detected
	at compile time, or \Node%
{\def\Element%
{3517}}\Seq%
{\def\fFamName{LucidaTypewriter}\def\fSize%
{9\p@}}xterm -e R\endSeq{}\endNode{} if Gnome was
	not found. Please note that (at present) at most three
	space-separated elements in this command string will be
	processed; any extra elements are ignored.
      \endPar{}\endNode{}\endSeq{}\endSpS{}\endNode{}\Node%
